front.p: 1843 March 8: Octavius Hadfield to his father Joseph

body.p: I lately received at letter from Julia (dated Sep. 28th.) in which she sends me a message from you to desire me to write when I have an opportunity; having now a few minutes to write in I do so, as there is a vessel going almost immediately - I was happy to hear that you were pretty well at the time of Julia's writing. It gives me great pleasure to hear from & about you all, but your letters do not reach me very regularly. I wrote a long letter to Caroline about 4 or 6 weeks ago, in which I mentioned my poor friend Mason's death & my narrow escape which you I trust will have received before this reaches you. I have lately had a pleasant visit to Queen Charlotte's Sound & I find the natives there as attentive as ever & as desirous of receiving instruction. They seem to care for little else than religion & are regardless of worldly concerns to their own detriment in some measure; but as they are following the scriptural command of "seeking first the Kingdom of God & His righteousness" I trust that they will have the blessing of God upon their temporal concerns, & that they may be preserved amidst the dangers to which they are exposed by the habits etc. of our countrymen.

I have now more to do than ever since Mason's death; but my strength I think is as great as it ever is, & I am quite well. I am come over over here for two days, on some matters of business & then return. Things are rather in a dull state in this place. I am with some others making some exertions to get the natives to work at the N.Z. Flax, which will be much for their benefit & it is almost essential to the welfare of this colony that they should have some export. They have always been trying to invent some machine for the preparation of the flax, but I think that I have convinced some that the natives could immediately prepare sufficient to form an annual export of £200,000 which would be an immediate benefit to this country. You need not however think that I employ any time in these matters: they are merely facts which force themselves upon the observation of those who go about with their eyes open which all here do not.
I shall hear again shortly from you, disappointed very often on the arrival of ships.
Give my kindest regards to the Warrens & all our friends, especially the [Ivins] if you write - & my affectionate love to my mother & brothers & sisters.
